WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mary E. McLean
Address: 7 Fairlight, Sask.
Birthplace: N.W.M.S.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1915
Where did you set up housekeeping? S.E. 4-14-32-W6 Sask.
Where had you been living before that? St. Croix Falls, Minn., U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6 to 14
How far was it to your nearest store? 2 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? 4 or 5 times a year
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, matches, tobacco, yeast, catsup, dried fruit, Baking Powder, flour.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Cook's Pride Flour

In what quantities did you buy it? 16 bags per year
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $6.00
How much did you use graham flour? 2 lbs. per year
Whole wheat flour? 2 lbs. per year
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 40 cents
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? 50 cents
Whole wheat? 50 cents
Oats? 50 cents
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With a hand mill.
McLean, Mrs. Mary E.
Fairlight, 1902
